title: 111_hr1998
content: The Act titled "Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2009" is referred to as the short title. The Congress acknowledges the challenges faced by emergency physicians and trauma surgeons in making critical decisions under time constraints and without a prior relationship with the patient, leading to increased medical liability claims. Younger surgeons are leaving States with severe liability problems, citing malpractice costs as a major reason. Hospitals in crisis States struggle to recruit physicians and have less coverage in emergency departments, leading to the closure of trauma centers in some areas. The closure of trauma centers in several states due to soaring medical liability premiums, particularly affecting specialties like neurosurgery, orthopaedics, and general surgery. Specialists reducing on-call services to hospital emergency departments, hindering patient access to emergency surgical services. Professional liability insurance is a significant concern recognized by the EMTALA technical advisory group. The EMTALA technical advisory group recognized the concern of professional liability insurance for providers, recommending amending the EMTALA statute to include liability protection for hospitals and practitioners in the emergency department. The Act is based on Congress's constitutional authority to provide for the general welfare, regulate commerce, and make necessary laws. It also includes protection for emergency and related services provided under EMTALA. Section 224(g) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 233(g)) is amended to include provisions for entities described in subparagraph (B) to be considered under paragraph (4) with certain exceptions. The amendment to Section 224(g) of the Public Health Service Act allows entities described in subparagraph (B) to be considered under paragraph (4) with exceptions related to services provided under section 1867 of the Social Security Act and post stabilization services. The amendment to Section 224(g) of the Public Health Service Act allows entities described in subparagraph (B) to be considered under paragraph (4) with exceptions related to causes of action arising from acts or omissions on or after January 1, 2010. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary, will make separate estimates and establish separate funds for entities described in subparagraph (B) and entities in paragraph (4) (excluding those in subparagraph (B)). Appropriations for entities in subparagraph (B) will be kept separate. Entities described in subparagraph (B) include hospitals, emergency departments under section 1867 of the Social Security Act, and physicians or physician groups. The fund established by the Secretary for these entities may exceed $10,000,000 for a fiscal year, and subsection (m) does not apply to them. Entities described in subparagraph (B) include hospitals, emergency departments, and physicians or physician groups. A physician or physician group may be employed by, under contract with, or an on-call provider for a hospital or emergency department to provide services under section 1867 of the Social Security Act. An on-call provider has staff privileges at a hospital or emergency department and agrees to be available to provide services as needed. The Social Security Act allows for post-stabilization services to individuals treated in hospitals or emergency departments, related to the condition treated and provided after stabilization to maintain or improve the individual's condition. The Social Security Act allows for post-stabilization services to individuals treated in hospitals or emergency departments. The Secretary is not authorized to make payments to entities without prior budget appropriation. Total payments for a fiscal year are limited to the amount appropriated in advance. The Social Security Act limits payments for post-stabilization services to the amount appropriated in advance for each fiscal year.
